subject: JUnit4 and legacy classes with static Test suite()
msgSnippet: Hi, I m doing some tests to see how easy it would be for us to upgrade to JUnit4. Ideally the new runner should be able to run all of our existing JUnit3.8
messageBody:
Hi,

I'm doing some tests to see how easy it would be for us to upgrade to
JUnit4. Ideally the new runner should be able to run all of our
existing JUnit3.8 tests without modifications.

The Cookbook suggests to use
org.junit.runner.TextListener.run(TestClass1.class, ...) as
TestRunner; but looks like that bit of documentation is out of date.

Apparently JUnitCore is the class that does the job. In fact it works
very well with regular TestCases. But it doesn't seem to recognize
classes with a static Test suite() method. E.g.

$ java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore some.junit38.tests.StaticSuiteTest
JUnit version 4.1
.E
Time: 0.018
There was 1 failure:
1) warning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1)
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: No tests found in
some.junit38.tests.StaticSuiteTest

while with the old runner

$ java junit.textui.TestRunner some.junit38.tests.StaticSuiteTest
..........
Time: 0.004
OK (10 tests)

If I annotate the legacy StaticSuiteTest with @RunWith(AllTests.class)
then the new runner is happy. But that means having to find out all
classes using static suite() in our codebase, annotate and recompile them.

Before delving into the new JUnit code, is this behaviour expected?

Thanks

Mirko
